io/serial.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /**
00002  * @file io/serial.h
00003  *
00004  * Interface to a serial interface (wow, an interface of an interface... :-)
00005  *
00006  * The prototypes contained in this file can be implemented multiple times to be
00007  * adapted to different communication interfaces which can simulate a serial
00008  * port (e.g. a real serial port, a TCP socket, a Unix socket,...).
00009  */
00010 
00011 
00012 #pragma once
00013 
00014 
00015 /**
00016  * Initializes the serial port using the values contained in the given struct.
00017  * The type of the struct is not defined to allow each implementation to use
00018  * a struct containing the values needed to set up its own communication
00019  * interface.
00020  *
00021  * For example, an implementation which connects to a serial port uses a struct
00022  * which contains values to define the speed, partity and stop bits of the
00023  * interface, while a testing implementation which simulates a serial port using
00024  * a TCP socket needs to know the values for the host and port to which
00025  * establish the connection.
00026  *
00027  * @param[in] config_struct  An implementation dependent struct to hold the
00028  *                           needed configuration settings.
00029  * @return  0 if the initialization process ended sucessfully, an error code
00030  *          otherwise.
00031  */
00032 int serial_init(const void * config_struct);
00033 
00034 
00035 /**
00036  * Reads a single char from a serial interface, blocking until some character
00037  * data is received.
00038  *
00039  * @pre   The \c serial_init function was already called and returned
00040  *        sucessfully.
00041  * @todo  How can we handle errors of this function? Setting a timeout limit and
00042  *        a special return code could do the trick.
00043  *
00044  * @return  The char read from the communication device.
00045  */
00046 char serial_readchar();
00047 
00048 
00049 /**
00050  * Reads data from the communication device until a newline character is
00051  * encountered, then saves the data to the buffer and returns the number of
00052  * bytes read.
00053  *
00054  * @pre   The \c serial_init function was already called and returned
00055  *        sucessfully.
00056  * @post  The data saved to the buffer does not contain any newline characters
00057  *        and is \\0 terminated.
00058  *
00059  * @todo  Should we set a timeout option? Should we allow to configure the char
00060  *        sequence to identify a line break (\\n, \\r\\n or \\r)?
00061  * @todo  Define the possible error numbers and their respective meaning.
00062  *
00063  * @param[out] buffer  The pointer to the string buffer to which the read line
00064  *                     has to be written.
00065  *
00066  * @return  The number of characters written to the buffer if the operation
00067  *          completed successfully, a negative error code otherwise.
00068  */
00069 int serial_readline(char * buffer);
00070 
00071 
00072 /**
00073  * Writes the data contained in the given character buffer to the communication
00074  * device until the end of the string (\\0).
00075  *
00076  * @pre   The \c serial_init function was already called and returned
00077  *        sucessfully.
00078  * @pre   The \a buffer string is correctly \\0 terminated.
00079  *
00080  * @param[in] buffer  The string to write to the serial interface.
00081  *
00082  * @return  The number of characters written if the operation completed
00083  *          successfully, a negative error code otherwise.
00084  */
00085 int serial_write(const char * buffer);
